pullRequest.title: Add support to the REST Client API to call the ‘normal' Search REST API
pullRequest.bodyText:
#1306
Checklist

 the [contributor license agreement][] is signed
 commit message follows [commit guidelines][]
 tests are included

Description of change
In oeq-ts-rest-api, add support to interact with the new search endpoint search2, including:

adding TS interfaces to help ensure the returned data structure is correct; and
adding functions to call the endpoint and validate data; and
adding a JEST test.

commit.message:
oeq-ts-rest-api: Add support for searching by the new REST search endpoint.
This includes: models for search result, a function calling the 'search2'
and check the type of returned data and one Jest test.

Add 'paramsSerializer' to the GET method in order to pass an
array as a query parameter.

nodes.bodyText:
The reason to add this is because the default query string format for array is not accepted on oEQ Server.
For example, /search2/?status[]=xxx&status[]=yyy  is not OK but /search2/?status=xxx&status=yyy is fine.
Anybody have better ideas?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -19,7 +20,7 @@ export const GET = <T>(
   queryParams?: object
 ): Promise<T> =>
   axios
-    .get<T>(path, {params: queryParams})
+    .get<T>(path, {params: queryParams, paramsSerializer: params => stringify(params)}, )

nodes.bodyText:
I feel this Jest test is more focused on validating the returned data type and handling errors rather than checking if the search result is correct or not.
We have another test Search2ApiTest which check the search results.
Please add JSDoc at the interface level too.
No need for this to be in its own stand-alone function. You'll see the others have just defined it where used. I see you've also exported it, but AFAICT it's not needed anywhere else.

File level comments:

All the interfaces here should be in either Common and over in Search, there's no need for this file; and
All of the interfaces in this file are missing JSDoc.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,50 @@
+import * as Common from './Common';

nodes.bodyText: We believe (thanks to the recent updates from @ChristianMurphy ), that we don't need this if you define the test as async and use await for the API call - see the other tests.

Missing JSDoc.
Keep in mind the pattern is that searchPath is just meant to be apiBasePath. It then uses that to build the full path so that the caller does not need to worry about the routes etc. (See others as examples.)
As mentioned in Search.ts, this path should be internalised to Search.ts.

I wonder if instead we should use https://www.npmjs.com/package/query-string
Only because it's been updated lately (2 months vs 7 years) and seems a bit more widely used.
It is also interesting that you could pull this in without adding anything to package.json. 🤔
(And as a real minor sidenote, interest that this is in double quotes where the others are in single quotes - I wonder if you ran Prettier over this...)

commit.message:
Use the library 'query-string' to serialize query params.

Don't need 'SearchResult' so move its code to 'Search' and remove it.

Use async/await to call the search api in the test.

Add more JSDoc.

nodes.bodyText: Are these statuses fixed/static? Or are they customizable at an institution level?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,210 @@
+import * as Common from './Common';
+import { is } from 'typescript-is';
+import {GET} from './AxiosInstance';
+
+/**
+ * Type of query parameters that can be used in a search.
+ */
+export interface SearchParams {
+  /**
+   * Query string.
+   */
+  query?: string;
+  /**
+   * The first record of the search results to return.
+   */
+  start?: number;
+  /**
+   * The number of results to return.
+   */
+  length?: number;
+  /**
+   * List of collections.
+   */
+  collections?: string[];
+  /**
+   * The order of the search results.
+   */
+  order?: string;
+  /**
+   * Reverse the order of the search results.
+   */
+  reverseOrder?: boolean;
+  /**
+   * An advanced search UUID.
+   */
+  advancedSearch?: string;
+  /**
+   * A where clause.
+   */
+  whereClause?: string;
+  /**
+   * Item status.
+   */
+  status?: ItemStatus[];
+  /**
+   * A date before which items are modified. Date format (yyyy-MM-dd).
+   */
+  modifiedBefore?: string;
+  /**
+   * A date after which items are modified. Date format (yyyy-MM-dd).
+   */
+  modifiedAfter?: string;
+  /**
+   * An ID of a user.
+   */
+  owner?: string;
+  /**
+   * single dynamic collection uuid.
+   */
+  dynaCollection?: string;
+}
+
+export enum ItemStatus {
+  DRAFT = "DRAFT",
+  LIVE = "LIVE",
+  REJECTED = "REJECTED",
+  MODERATING = "MODERATING",
+  ARCHIVED = "ARCHIVED",
+  SUSPENDED = "SUSPENDED",
+  DELETED = "DELETED",
+  REVIEW = "REVIEW",
+  PERSONAL = "PERSONAL",
+}

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * Type of item's display fields.
          
          
            
             * Details of an additional field to display as part of search results - server side configurable in collections.
I imagine this should be over in Common as it's not unique to search results, and so later when working with Items we'll most likely use it again.

Could we please match the namespaced import style as done in the other tests?
So instead go with the:
import * as OEQ from '../src';

And then below you'd do your calls for example with:
OEQ.Search.search(TC.API_PATH)

We need to be thorough with the JSDoc. Here you're missing the @param statements.
You should just be able to copy across the definitely for apiBasePath from the others - to keep it consistent. And then add one for params.
Long term - if we do this right - when we build it as it's own module, we can also publish the JSDocs for easy reference on a github pages setup. Further, the doco assists with IDE integrated doco.

commit.message:
Add a function that converts types of an object's certain fields to Date.

Add a Jest test for the function.

Add an optional parameter to GET, which allows data structure transformation
as required.

nodes.bodyText: The type of data should be T so I am concerned about if using any will break type safety.
The returning type is unknown because the object is modified so it might be no longer of its original type. This is my understanding but I am not very sure if I am right.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,29 @@
+import * as Lodash from "lodash";
+
+/**
+ * Return a copied object of which types of specified fields are converted to Date.
+ * @param fields Names of fields that need type conversion.
+ * @param data The object to be processed. Nested objects will be processed, too.
+ * @param cloneData True if deep clone is required.
+ */
+export const convertDateFields = <T>(fields: string[], data: T, cloneData: boolean): unknown => {

nodes.bodyText:
I think we're now at a point where this function needs some JSDoc to support future maintenance. Although it's primarily internal, I think it'll help with it's consumption going forward. Maybe something like:
/**
 * Executes a HTTP GET for a given path.
 *
 * @param path The URL path for the target GET
 * @param validator A function to perform runtime type checking against the result - typically with typescript-is
 * @param queryParams The query parameters to send with the GET request
 * @param transformer A function which returns a copy of the raw data from the GET with any required values transformed - this should NOT mutate the input data (transforms should start on a copy/clone of the input)
 */
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -16,17 +17,19 @@ const catchHandler = (error: AxiosError | Error): never => {
 export const GET = <T>(

nodes.bodyText:
I think we've got this the wrong way about.
Really, it's the data returned from axios.get() which is potentially unknown. So maybe the axios.get<T>() should drop the generic and just do axios.get(). Then, the signature for the transformer should be:
(data: unknown) => T

Because it's still a blind transform (i.e. the validator hasn't be run yet) you could argue the return should still be unknown. But I guess the argument is we're expecting it to return T and then we're simply validating it.
So how about we make the above two changes - that's the axios.get call, and the signature for the transformer?

I think that's right, but I'd also argue the input too is also unknown - or more so, does not have to be known consider we don't use any of the type information here - we've mostly resorted to metaprogramming.

+

+ * @param fields Names of fields that need type conversion.
+ * @param data The object to be processed. Nested objects will be processed, too.
+ * @param cloneData True if deep clone is required.
+ */
+export const convertDateFields = <T>(fields: string[], data: T, cloneData: boolean): unknown => {

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
             * Return a copied object of which types of specified fields are converted to Date.
          
          
            
             * @param fields Names of fields that need type conversion.
          
          
            
             * @param data The object to be processed. Nested objects will be processed, too.
          
          
            
             * @param cloneData True if deep clone is required.
          
          
            
             * Return a clone of the provided object with specified fields converted to type Date. A deep clone
          
          
            
             * will be undertaken, and so nested fields with matching names will also be converted.
          
          
            
             *
          
          
            
             * @param fields List of the names of fields to convert.
          
          
            
             * @param data The object to be processed.
          
          
            
             * @param cloneData True if deep clone is required.

+ * Return a copied object of which types of specified fields are converted to Date.
+ * @param fields Names of fields that need type conversion.
+ * @param data The object to be processed. Nested objects will be processed, too.
+ * @param cloneData True if deep clone is required.

nodes.bodyText:
I fear this block has now become a bit unreadable and unwieldly. But we can tidy it up with filter I feel. e.g.
targetFields
  .filter(targetField => targetField === field)
  .forEach(field => (input as any)[field] = converter(value));

to ensure validator is a predicate use

commit.message:
Move date string validation to the date specific converter.

Import 'cloneDeep' rather than the whole library of lodash.
